start.speaker: Pixel
start.text: Level 4 - LOOPS! The secret to not repeating yourself a million times! ðŸ”„
start.followUp: Imagine typing 'spawn enemy' 100 times... Nah! Let's make Python do the repetitive work!

loopImportance.speaker: Pixel
loopImportance.text: Games are ALL about loops! The game loop runs 60 times per second, checking inputs, updating positions, drawing graphics!
loopImportance.followUp: Without loops, games couldn't exist! Let's master them!

whileLoop.speaker: Pixel
whileLoop.text: The 'while' loop keeps running as long as something is true - like 'while game is running'!
whileLoop.codeExample:
health = 100

while health > 0:
    print(f'Still alive! HP: {health}')
    health = health - 20
    
print('Game Over!')
whileLoop.followUp: It checks the condition, runs the code, then checks again. Repeat until false!

infiniteLoop.speaker: Pixel
infiniteLoop.text: Ah, the dreaded infinite loop! If the condition never becomes false, it runs FOREVER!
infiniteLoop.codeExample:
# DON'T RUN THIS!
while True:
    print('This never stops!')
    
# Better - with an exit condition:
running = True
turns = 0

while running:
    turns += 1
    print(f'Turn {turns}')
    if turns >= 5:
        running = False
infiniteLoop.followUp: Always make sure your loop has a way to end, or your game will freeze!

options.text: How do I control loops better?

whileExamples.speaker: Pixel
whileExamples.text: Here's a mini game loop - collecting coins until you have enough!
whileExamples.codeExample:
coins = 0
goal = 50

while coins < goal:
    print(f'Coins: {coins}/{goal}')
    found = 10  # Found 10 coins!
    coins += found
    print(f'Found {found} coins!')
    
print(f'Success! You collected {coins} coins!')
whileExamples.followUp: Perfect for any 'keep doing until' situation in games!

breakContinue.speaker: Pixel
breakContinue.text: 'break' and 'continue' give you superpowers over loops!
breakContinue.followUp: 'break' is the emergency exit, 'continue' is the skip button!

forLoop.speaker: Pixel
forLoop.text: The 'for' loop is perfect when you know how many times to repeat - like spawning 5 enemies!
forLoop.codeExample:
# Spawn exactly 5 enemies
for enemy_number in range(5):
    print(f'Spawning enemy #{enemy_number + 1}')
    
# range(5) gives us: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
forLoop.followUp: The range() function is your best friend for counting!

options.text: Can I loop through other things?

rangeFunction.speaker: Pixel
rangeFunction.text: range() is super flexible! You can control start, stop, and step!
rangeFunction.followUp: range(start, stop, step) - remember, it NEVER includes the stop value!

options.text: What else can I loop through?

forIterables.speaker: Pixel
forIterables.text: You can loop through ANYTHING that's a collection - strings, lists, even dictionaries later!
forIterables.codeExample:
# Loop through a string
word = 'PIXEL'
for letter in word:
    print(f'Give me a {letter}!')
    
# Loop through a list (preview!)
inventory = ['sword', 'shield', 'potion']
for item in inventory:
    print(f'You have: {item}')
    
# Loop with index
for index, item in enumerate(inventory):
    print(f'Slot {index + 1}: {item}')
forIterables.followUp: For loops make it easy to process every item in a collection!

nestedLoops.speaker: Pixel
nestedLoops.text: Nested loops are loops inside loops - perfect for grids, like game boards!
nestedLoops.codeExample:
# Create a 3x3 grid
for row in range(3):
    for col in range(3):
        print(f'({row},{col})', end=' ')
    print()  # New line after each row
    
# Output:
# (0,0) (0,1) (0,2)
# (1,0) (1,1) (1,2)
# (2,0) (2,1) (2,2)
nestedLoops.followUp: The inner loop runs completely for each iteration of the outer loop!

tileExample.speaker: Pixel

gameExample.speaker: Pixel
gameExample.text: Let's build a complete battle system with loops!
gameExample.codeExample:
# Turn-based combat
player_hp = 100
enemy_hp = 150
turn = 0

while player_hp > 0 and enemy_hp > 0:
    turn += 1
    print(f'\n--- Turn {turn} ---')
    
    # Player attacks
    damage = 25
    enemy_hp -= damage
    print(f'You deal {damage} damage!')
    
    if enemy_hp <= 0:
        print('Victory!')
        break
        
    # Enemy attacks
    damage = 15
    player_hp -= damage
    print(f'Enemy deals {damage} damage!')
    
    print(f'Your HP: {player_hp} | Enemy HP: {enemy_hp}')

if player_hp <= 0:
    print('Defeat...')
gameExample.followUp: See how the loop handles the entire battle? That's the power of loops!

forElse.followUp: Super useful for search operations in games!
